descript.abstract:
This layer contains data for those parts of the sewer interceptor system in the Twin Cities metropolitan area that have been removed from service (but not removed from the ground)
The interceptor system provides the link from community sewer systems to the wastewater treatment facilities in the seven county metropolitan area.
descript.purpose: To provide a digital inventory of Metropolitan Council, Environmental Services division abandoned pipelines.
descript.supplinf: Twin Cities 7 County Metropolitan Area. This includes the counties of Anoka, Carver, Dakota, Hennepin, Ramsey, Scott and Washington in Minnesota.

timeperd.current: dataset is up-to-date as of specified date.

theme.themekey: utilities, abandoned sewer interceptors, sewer, sewers, waste water, sewage, sewerage, sewer interceptors, sewer systems

place.placekey: Twin Cities, Anoka County, Carver County, Dakota County, Hennepin County, Ramsey County, Scott County, Washington County

browse.browsed: Sample map showing the AbandonedInterceptors layer.

citeinfo.title: Sewer Interceptors, Sewer Interceptor Lift Stations, Sewer Interceptor Meter Stations

dataqual.complete: Between 1970 (formation of Sewer Board) and 1990 (formation of ES GIS) several interceptors were abandoned or reconveyed and were not included in the original GIS inventory. This dataset is incomplete and should not be used as a definative system.

horizpa.horizpar: The positional accuracy of the dataset has not been tested under the National Standards for Spatial Data Accuracy. The positional accuracy of the dataset is estimated to be 20 ft.

procstep.procdesc:
This dataset was derived from as-built plan drawings. The data were transferred to ETAK street base files and later converted to match a 1992 (?) Minnesota Department of Transportation street base.
The Metropolitan Council is in the process of developing parallel data using GPS locations for more accurate positioning.

overview.eaover:
LINE ATTRIBUTES
ID-NO: Text identifier of interceptor
PIPE-SHAPE: Pipe shape (circular, horseshoe, etc.)
PIPE-TYPE: Pipe material
X-INCH: Pipe dimension value (x-axis inches)
Y-INCH: Pipe dimension value (y-axis inches)
LENGTH_FT: Point-to-point section length (feet)
SYMBOL: 1 = gravity, 2 = force main, 3 = siphon, 4 = outfall, 5 = low-head, 6 = non-MCES pipe connecting remote MCES point to interceptors, 8 = bypass
SURF-TYPE: Surface type (bituminous, gravel, ground, etc.)
YR-BUILT: Year constructed
PROJECT: Construction project nomenclature
ALTER-ID: Alternate name
LS-NO: Associated Lift Station Number (Forcemain only)
NOTES: Notes
INTERCEPT: Numeric ID for interceptor
SECTION: Hydraulic section ID (obsolete)
SECT_ID: Section ID based on downstream point-to-point
INT-SECT: Unique relate field based on INTERCEPT and SECT_ID
DIMEN: Text version of pipe dimension
WWTP: Treatment plant to which interceptor flows
BASIN: MCES defined treatment plant shed
METER: Flow meter to which the pipe is tributary
FROMPNT: UNIQUE_ID at upstream end of section
TOPNT: UNIQUE_ID at downstream end of section
MEAS_BEG: Linear location of INT_SECT beginning
MEAS_END: Linear location of INT_SECT ending
YR_INSP: Year last inspected (semi-populated)
MO_INSP: Month last inspected (semi-populated)
YR_ABAN: Year abandoned or reconveyed

You are responsible for any consequences resulting from your use of the GIS Data or your reliance on the GIS Data. You should consult the data documentation for this particular GIS Data to determine the limitations of the GIS Data and the precision with which the GIS Data may depict distance, direction, location, or other geographic features. If you transmit or provide the GIS Data (or any portion of it) to another user, it is recommended that the GIS Data include a copy of this disclaimer and this metadata.
